intro: Alseis involuta, commonly known as the twisted alseis, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Ericaceae family, which includes heathers and blueberries, and is characterized by its evergreen foliage. The plant produces small, bell-shaped white or pink flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are elliptical and often have a slightly wavy margin, contributing to its distinctive appearance. Alseis involuta typically grows in moist, acidic soils in shaded to partially shaded environments.
